Prepovedali oblačenje v ameriške vojake
Berlinčani praznujejo 30. obletnico padca zidu. Organizirali 200 dogodkov.
07 Nov 2019, 14:38 by U. S.



Ostanki zidu na ulici Bornholmer.



Svetlobna instalacija.



Dolgih 28 let je zid delil Berlin in Nemčijo. FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images



Prebivalci zahodnega dela mesta so se veselili z rojaki iz vzhodnega dela Berlina. FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images



V ameriške vojake preoblečeni igralci so turistom na Checkpoint Charlieju zaračunavali za fotografije. FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images


Günther Schabowski je okleval, se popraskal po glavi, nataknil očala in brskal po zapiskih. Kot bi poskušal razumeti, kaj piše, da bi novinarki odgovoril na vprašanje o tem, kdaj bodo začeli veljati ukrepi, ki odpravljajo omejitve potovanja Vzhodnih Nemcev v tujino, tudi v zahodni del Berlina. »Kolikor vem, takoj zdaj,« je vendarle odgovoril. Bil je 9. november 1989. Vlak zgodovinskih sprememb je v tistem trenutku zapeljal s perona. Schabowski, član politbiroja vzhodnonemške komunistične stranke in njen predstavnik, je v tistem trenutku oznanil padec berlinskega zidu. Nekaj novinarjev, prepričanih, da gre za še eno dolgočasno birokratsko novinarsko konferenco, ni moglo verjeti svojim ušesom. Zdelo se je, kot da je Schabowski besede izrekel kar tako, nepripravljen na novinarsko vprašanje.
9. novembra 1989 je padel berlinski zid.


Prebivalci zahodnega dela mesta so se veselili z rojaki iz vzhodnega dela Berlina. FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images

Še 30 let pozneje traja debata, ali je bil nenaden padec zidu, uvod v razpad vzhodnega bloka, naključje, posledica lapsusa. Morda rezultat nesporazuma med komunistično hierarhijo, presenečeno nad razvojem dogodkov, ali preračunljiva gesta oblastnikov, ki so spoznali, da so na koncu poti? Schabowski je moral v živo na televiziji razložiti nove ukrepe o potovanju. Ideja je bila, da se dopustijo nadzorovana potovanja z obveznim vizumom, ne pa da se čez noč poruši zid, z njim vred pa tudi Vzhodna Nemčija oziroma Nemška demokratična republika.A vrnitve nazaj ni bilo več. Po njegovem govoru na konferenci je več tisoč Berlinčanov pohitelo k zidu, dolgemu 150 kilometrov, ki je med letoma 1961 in 1989 ločeval Berlin na vzhodni in zahodni del. Pohiteli so k mejnim prehodom in zahtevali njihovo odprtje. Obmejna vojska še ni bila obveščena o odprtju meja, a so pod pritiskom množice do 23. ure odprli prehod Bornholmer Strasse, pozneje pa še druge. V poznih večernih urah so ljudje odprtje spremljali po televiziji, mnogo pa se jih je odpravilo k prehodom. Zahodnjaki so odprtih rok sprejemali rojake iz vzhodnega dela mesta, večina gostiln v bližini je delila brezplačno pivo, na Kurfürstendammu se je zbirala množica voznikov, ki so trobili v pozdrav. V 500 kilometrov oddaljenem Bonnu, takratni prestolnici zahodne Zvezne republike Nemčije, so v parlamentu prekinili sejo in spontano zapeli himno. Vse televizijske postaje so tistega večera v posebnem programu poročale o Berlinčanih, ki »plešejo na zidu pred Brandenburškimi vrati in slavijo konec nekega obdobja«. Prav tam, pred Brandenburškimi vrati, bo v soboto vrhunec praznovanja 30. obletnice padca zidu, zgodovinskih dogodkov pa se pod geslom 30 let mirne revolucije in padca zidu na sedmih zgodovinskih krajih spominjajo z 200 dogodki, od koncertov do razstav. Danes je od berlinskega zidu ostalo le malo, najbolj znan ostanek stoji med Hauptbahnhofom in Oberbaumbrückejem, je državni spomenik. Sled, kjer je stal zid, je ponekod še vedno dobro vidna, večinoma tam vodi kolesarska steza.
Tiste noči je bila največja ulična zabava, Berlinčani so plesali na zidu, gostilne so delile pivo.


V ameriške vojake preoblečeni igralci so turistom na Checkpoint Charlieju zaračunavali za fotografije. FOTO: Guliver/Getty Images

Mimogrede, v Berlinu so igralcem prepovedali preoblačenje v ameriške vojake in poziranje s turisti na znameniti nadzorni točki Checkpoint Charlie, nekdanjem prehodu, ki je ločeval vzhodni in zahodni del mesta. Berlinski mestni očetje menijo, da igralci izkoriščajo turiste, saj fotografiranje zaračunavajo. Zato so odvzeli dovoljenje za nastop skupini Dance Factory, čeprav njeni člani trdijo, da so sprejemali le prostovoljne prispevke. A so v turiste preoblečeni policisti ugotovili, da v resnici skupina za fotografijo računa štiri evre, tiste, ki jim nočejo plačati, pa zmerjajo.

Prohibited dressing in US troops
Berliners are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the fall of the wall. Organized 200 events.
07 Nov 2019, 14:38 by U. S.



The remains of a wall on Bornholmer Street.



Light installation.



For 28 years, the wall has divided Berlin and Germany. PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images



Residents of the western part of the city rejoiced with compatriots from the eastern part of Berlin. PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images



Players in disguised players were charged by tourists at Checkpoint Charlie for photos. PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images


Günther Schabowski hesitated, scratched his head, put on his glasses, and browsed through the notes. As if trying to understand what it says, the reporter would answer the question of when measures that lift restrictions on East German travel abroad would come into force, including in western Berlin. "As far as I know, right now," he replied. It was November 9, 1989. At that moment, a train of historic change took off from the platform. Schabowski, a politburo member of the East German Communist Party and its representative, announced the fall of the Berlin wall at the time. A few journalists, convinced that this was another boring bureaucratic press conference, couldn't believe their ears. It seemed as if Schabowski had uttered the words quite so, unprepared for the press.
On November 9, 1989, the Berlin Wall fell.


Residents of the western part of the city rejoiced with compatriots from the eastern part of Berlin. PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images

30 years later, the debate over whether the sudden collapse of the wall, the introduction to the collapse of the eastern bloc, was a coincidence was the result of a lapse. Perhaps the result of a misunderstanding between the communist hierarchy, astonished by the developments, or the calculable gesture of the rulers who realized they were at the end of the road? Schabowski had to explain the new travel arrangements live on television. The idea was to allow controlled travel with a compulsory visa, not to break the wall overnight, as well as East Germany and the German Democratic Republic. But there was no turning back. According to his speech at the conference, thousands of Berliners hurried to the 150-kilometer-long wall that separated Berlin from the east and the west between 1961 and 1989. They hurried to the border crossings and demanded their opening. The Border Army had not yet been notified of the opening of the borders, but under pressure from the crowd, the Bornholmer Strasse passage was opened by 11pm and later by others. In the late evening, people watched the opening on TV, and many went to the aisles. Westerners received open-mouthed compatriots from the eastern part of the city, most of the pubs in the neighborhood shared free beer, and a crowd of drivers shouting farewell at Kurfürstendamm. Within 500 kilometers of Bonn, then the capital of the western Federal Republic of Germany, the parliament adjourned the session and sang the anthem spontaneously. All television stations reported that evening in a special program about the Berliners "dancing on the wall outside the Brandenburg Gate and celebrating the end of a period." Right there, in front of the Brandenburg Gate, will mark the culmination of the 30th anniversary of the fall of the wall on Saturday, with 200 events ranging from concerts to exhibitions to commemorate 30 years of peaceful revolution and the fall of the wall in seven historic places. Today, little is left of the Berlin wall, the most famous remains standing between the Hauptbahnhof and Oberbaumbrücke, is a national monument. The trail where the wall stood can still be seen in some places, most of which is where the cycle track runs.
That night was the biggest street party, the Berliners were dancing on the wall, the pubs were brewing beer.


Players in disguised players were charged by tourists at Checkpoint Charlie for photos. PHOTO: Gulliver / Getty Images

By the way, in Berlin, players were banned from changing into US soldiers and posing with tourists at the famous Checkpoint Charlie checkpoint, a former passage that separated the city's east and west. Berlin's city fathers say players are taking advantage of tourists as they charge for photography. As a result, they have withdrawn their permission to perform at the Dance Factory Group, although its members claim that they have only accepted voluntary contributions. However, the tourist-turned-police officers realized that in reality the photography group was counting four euros, and those who refuse to pay them are moderation.
